awd_titl_txt: Creating FAIR Data in Lake Observatories of the Future
awd_abstract_narration:
Lake observatories produce data critical to the development of insights into the response of ecosystems to the global demands on freshwater resources. To help scientists study these issues, and to inspire educators and the public to learn about and further appreciate the importance of lake ecosystems to human well being, lake observatories need to accelerate the rate at which their observational data can be discovered and used by others. Through organizing a conference around the FAIR principles (data that are Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable), the PIs propose to engage members of both the global lake ecology and the data and information science communities to identify and develop a roadmap by which lake observatories of the future can deliver FAIR data to researchers, managers, and the public. 

A one-and-a-half day workshop is planned for Spring 2020.  Attendees will represent key stakeholders from the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON), the data and informatics community emerging around FAIR, and affiliated observatory and international members.   The agenda will include reviewing lessons learned from current FAIR initiatives; gap identification and opportunities for lake observatories of the future; framework for discussing data valuation and longevity of data products from lake observatories; and use cases for edge computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lake sensor observatories play critically important roles in advancing understanding of fresh waters. These observatories are an unparalleled source of information on freshwater quality and quantity for scientists, educators, managers, and the general public. Synthesis of data from lake observatories has provided the foundation for remarkable scientific advances, opened the eyes of students to the power of big data for illuminating the patterns and processes of the natural world, and has been highly valued by community members interested in the current and future health of these ecosystems. Observatories are driving transformations in the way ecological science is conducted: use of automated environmental sensors is fueling rapid accumulation of data, the spread of wireless communication brings the presence of observatories to the desktops of everyone, and observatories around the world are increasingly used to help inform the public and managers of environmental issues. These high-frequency sensor data are at the core of convergent science, and provide the backbone of GLEON (the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network), an international, grassroots community of researchers and community members who advance lake science through, in part, deploying and analyzing data from observatories on lakes around the world.

Funding agencies, scientific journals, data repositories, the scientific community, and even the general public are recognizing the importance of access to, and re-use of, observatory data under the general umbrella of public access to data and FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and re-usable) principles. While momentum in ensuring that data are FAIR is growing, there remains a wide gap between the idea of FAIR and its implementation and practice in observatories, especially in the development of best practices within the ecological research community.

The original outcomes, as a result of a face-to-face workshop scheduled for April 2020, were anticipated to be co-exploration and documentation of barriers to creating and publishing FAIR data and the creation of a roadmap toward FAIR principles for lake observatories.  However, COVID intervened. With a pivot in process,  FAIR principles for observatories and observatory data were promoted  through: an initial virtual workshop to examine existing international best practices and gaps; incorporating FAIR data best practices and tools into presentations made and workshops held at national and international meetings,  including the North American Lake Management Society (NALMS) Annual meeting, and the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network  (GLEON) All Hands meetings in 2022 and 2023; explicitly promoting FAIR data practices  in the development of a data curation tool as part of an NSF, NE Spokes-funded project, the Ecological Long Tail, with an aim to publish resultant data in the NSF-funded Environmental Data Initiative (EDI) repository; and holding intra-lab data publishing workshops for lakes and reservoirs through which FAIR principles were applied.
